Other News

content:

- WTI crude US oil rose 1.1%.
- Iron ore fell nearly 1.0%.

subject: US Rep. Levin said that major issues remain after receiving briefing on NAFTA talks from US Trade Representative Lighthizer
ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASES CALENDAR NOW AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION: Highlights Include Australian HIA New Home Sales and Singapore PPI
US President Trump says we will make a trade deal with UK
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

BoJ's Governor Kuroda said we are finally close to the target and that inflationary expectation are picking up slightly, while he also repeated that the BoJ will continue to support the economy via monetary easing, medium-long term inflation expectations are expected to rise. (Newswires)


NORTH AMERICA

US President Trump plans to seek USD 716bln in defence spending, a massive increase that signals a shift away from concerns about deficits. (WaPo) Furthermore, there were also reports that draft of White House infrastructure plan would reduce environmental requirement for infrastructure projects. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said comments on USD were 'even-handed' and pointed out that where USD is in the short term is not a concern. (Newswires)

Mexican Deputy Economy Minister Baker said Mexico prioritises a good NAFTA deal over a fixed-time frame. He added that Mexico sees the presentation of auto ideas as a positive. (Newswires)

Canadian NAFTA negotiator said NAFTA talks could stretch into 2019 before deal, while there were comments from Canada that some progress was made in discussions. (Newswires)

 

EQUITIES: SPX +1.2% at 2872.87, DJI +0.9% at 26616.71, NDX +1.5% at 7,022.97.
Top sectors: Healthcare +2.2%, IT +1.7%, Cons Disc +1.0%
Bottom sectors: Utilities +0.1%, Materials +0.4%, Energy +0.6%

Stocks closed the week at fresh record highs, with the SPX printing a positive weekly close for the fourth consecutive week. Friday’s gains being led by healthcare. The defensive utilities sector was the laggard, but still green. Stock futures largely looked through the softer than expected US advanced GDP print for Q4, and instead took their cue from earnings. Solid earnings from Intel on Thursday helped boost tech stocks; Intel shares were up around 10% to 17-year highs and received a host of broker upgrades. Elsewhere on the earnings slate, Abbvie reported top- and bottom-line beat and raised guidance, and the story was similar for Honeywell. Colgate-Palmolive was more in-line with forecasts, while Nextera beat on EPS, but posted a small revenue miss.

Treasury yields were higher on Friday, with the underperformance mostly in the belly of the curve. The sell-off was inspired by a weaker than expected advanced GDP reading for Q4. The 2s30s, 5s10s and 5s30s curves all narrowed slightly, while 2s5s and 2s10s saw modest widening ahead of next week’s FOMC (2s rose to nine year highs), where the central bank is expected to stand pat in outgoing Fed chair Yellen’s final meeting. The Fed had forecast GDP growth of 2.5% in 2017, and as such, the Q4 data is a touch ahead of their forecasts, leaving it scope to continue on its hiking trajectory, where it has pencilled in three 2018 rate rises. 10-Year T-Note settles -12 ticks at 122-02..

 

DATA

US GDP Advance (Q4) 2.6% vs. Exp. 3.0% (Prev. 3.2%, Rev. 2.6%)
- US GDP Deflator Advance (Q4) 2.4% vs. Exp. 2.3% (Prev. 2.1%)
- US GDP Cons Spending Advance (Q4) 3.8% (Prev. 2.2%)
- US GDP Sales Advance (Q4) 3.2% vs. Exp. 3.2% (Prev. 2.4%)
- US PCE Prices Advance (Q4) 2.8% vs. Exp. 1.8% (Prev. 1.5%)
- US Core PCE Prices Advance (Q4) 1.9% vs. Exp. 1.6% (Prev. 1.3%)

US Adv Goods Trade Balance (Dec) -71.58B vs. Exp. -68.60B (Prev. -70.00B, Rev. -69.99B)
- US Retail Inventories Advance (Dec) 0.6% (Prev. 0.2%, Rev. 0.3%)
- US Wholesale Inventories Adv (Dec) 0.2% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.8%)

US Durable Goods (Dec) 2.9% vs. Exp. 0.8% (Prev. 1.3%, Rev. 1.7%)
- US Durables Ex-Defense MM (Dec) 2.2% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 1.0%, Rev. 1.5%)
- US Nondefe Cap Ex-Air (Dec) -0.3% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. -0.2%, Rev. 0.2%)
- US Durables Ex-Transport (Dec) 0.6% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. -0.1%,Rev. 0.3%)

Canadian CPI Inflation YY (Dec) 1.9% vs. Exp. 1.9% (Prev. 2.1%)
- Canadian CPI Inflation MM (Dec) -0.4% vs. Exp. -0.3% (Prev. 0.3%)
- Canadian CPI Common (Dec) 1.6% vs. Exp. 1.5% (Prev. 1.5%)
- Canadian CPI Trim (Dec) 1.9% (Prev. 1.8%)
- Canadian CPI Median (Dec) 1.9% (Prev. 1.9%)
- Canadian Core CPI MM SA (Dec) 0.1% (Prev. 0.2%)
- Canadian CPI MM SA (Dec) 0.2% (Prev. 0.5%)
- Canadian CPI BoC Core MM (Dec) -0.5% (Prev. -0.1%)
- Canadian CPI BoC Core YY (Dec) 1.2% (Prev. 1.3%)
 

EU/UK

Fitch affirmed Austria at AA+, outlook stable and affirmed France at AA, outlook stable. (Newswires)

ECB’s Knot stated that the ECB should make it clear how it will end its asset purchases after September when its current purchase program finishes and that there isn’t any reason to continue with bond purchases. Knot also stated that the current program should end ASAP, but noted it was better to continue the program until September for credibility. (Newswires)

EU's Moscovici said that the door was open if the UK wants to change its mind on Brexit. (Newswires)

US President Trump commented that he would be ‘Tougher’ than UK PM May in Brexit discussions with the EU. (Newswires)

 

FX

FOREX: DXY red for the sixth straight week

The DXY lost 0.5% on Friday trade, capping off a grim week – the sixth consecutive week of losses. The dollar was given some reprieve after US President Donald Trump’s comments on Thursday (which were on the face of it, contrary to the comments of his Treasury Secretary) when he expressed a desire for a “strong dollar”. However, he said that Treasury Secretary Mnuchin’s comments were apparently “even handed” and that where the buck is in the short-term was not a concern.

The EUR again took advantage of the dollar weakness, but failed to test the post-ECB highs printed on Thursday, with price action capped by the 1.25 handle. Next week the docket is packed full of ECB speakers (Coeure, Lautenschlager, Praet, Mersch) that will put into perspective the ECB’s latest meeting. Yesterday, sources stories suggested that the ECB remains split about its next move, and the immediate debate centres around when the ECB will amend its forward guidance (March seems to be the consensus).

The yen, meanwhile, was among the top performers in the G10 space after BOJ Governor Kuroda again said that he expects only moderate economic growth, and inflation expectations were rising slightly. The comments sent USDJPY to visit the 108.50 mark, and were clearly misinterpreted by the market; later in the session, a BOJ released a statement saying that the governor’s comments were not a revision of his views, prompting the yen to retreat to 109.

Other havens were bid on USD weakness, and gold continued its rise, settling above $1,350, but the yellow metal didn’t manage to test weekly highs around $1,366.

Sterling was lingering around the 1.42 mark, but has backed away from highs against the EUR, despite newsflow over the last couple of days suggesting that Europeans may be more open to a flexible approach to Brexit, including flexibility over the transitional period. On the data front, GDP growth was encouraging, and at 1.8% in 2017, is four times the level most analysts were forecasting after the Brexit referendum. In late US trade, the greenback found some strength, contributing to GBP weaknesss, and pushing cable down towards the 1.4150 area.

CAD advanced against the buck; although CPI fell, we are still knocking around the midpoint of the BOC tolerance band, and all three BOC metrics suggested that the inflationary landscape is firm.

 

COMMODITIES

WTI futures settle 63 cents higher at USD 66.14 per barrel, Brent futures settle 10 cents higher at USD 70.52 per barrel

Both Brent and WTI are rounding off a solid week, rising between 3% and 4%. There was no specific, meaningful crude related news explaining Friday’s gains, and analysts were content to attribute the rise to stronger stocks, a firmer dollar. Oil drillers added 12 rigs, according to Baker Hughes, the most since March, and the second rise in three weeks.

Iranian Oil Minister Zanganeh stated that output declined in some oil fields due to lack of resources and added that Iran will seek lower production in coming years if it cannot be fixed. (Newswires)

US Baker Hughes Total (Jan 26) 947 (Prev. 936)
- US Baker Hughes Gas (Jan 26) 188 (Prev. 189)
- US Baker Hughes Oil (Jan 26) 759 (Prev. 747)

 

GEOPOLITICS

Russia has no obligations to carry out one sided sanctions set by the USA, including North Korea. (Newswires)
